SELECT e.FirstName, e.LastName, AVG(so.TotalAmount) AS AverageOrderValue
FROM employees e
JOIN salesorders so ON e.EmployeeID = so.EmployeeID
GROUP BY e.FirstName, e.LastName
ORDER BY AverageOrderValue DESC
LIMIT 10
sql:
SELECT e.FirstName, e.LastName, AVG(so.TotalAmount) AS AverageOrderValue
FROM employees e
JOIN salesorders so ON e.EmployeeID = so.EmployeeID
GROUP BY e.FirstName, e.LastName
ORDER BY AverageOrderValue DESC
LIMIT 10

SELECT e.FirstName, e.LastName, SUM(so.TotalAmount) AS TotalSales,
      100 * SUM(so.TotalAmount) / (SELECT SUM(so2.TotalAmount) FROM salesorders so2 WHERE YEAR(so2.OrderDate) = 2024) AS RevenueShare
FROM employees e
JOIN salesorders so ON e.EmployeeID = so.EmployeeID
WHERE YEAR(so.OrderDate) = 2024
GROUP BY e.FirstName, e.LastName
sql:
SELECT e.FirstName, e.LastName, SUM(so.TotalAmount) AS TotalSales,
      100 * SUM(so.TotalAmount) / (SELECT SUM(so2.TotalAmount) FROM salesorders so2 WHERE YEAR(so2.OrderDate) = 2024) AS RevenueShare
FROM employees e
JOIN salesorders so ON e.EmployeeID = so.EmployeeID
WHERE YEAR(so.OrderDate) = 2024
GROUP BY e.FirstName, e.LastName

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
SELECT e.FirstName, e.LastName, GROUP_CONCAT(DISTINCT c.Industry) AS Industries
FROM employees e
JOIN salesorders so ON e.EmployeeID = so.EmployeeID
JOIN customers c ON so.CustomerID = c.CustomerID
GROUP BY e.EmployeeID
ORDER BY COUNT(DISTINCT c.Industry) DESC, e.FirstName, e.LastName
LIMIT 5
sql:
SELECT e.FirstName, e.LastName, GROUP_CONCAT(DISTINCT c.Industry) AS Industries
FROM employees e
JOIN salesorders so ON e.EmployeeID = so.EmployeeID
JOIN customers c ON so.CustomerID = c.CustomerID
GROUP BY e.EmployeeID
ORDER BY COUNT(DISTINCT c.Industry) DESC, e.FirstName, e.LastName
LIMIT 5
insights: The data shows that each of the five employees, Ananya Ansari, Advait Chandran, Divya Sen, Isha Srinivasan, and Saanvi Sen, have handled multiple industries in their roles. The number of industries handled by each employee is not identical but varies.

SELECT e.EmployeeID, COUNT(so.OrderID) AS Cancellations, (COUNT(so.OrderID) / total_orders.TotalOrders) AS CancellationRate
FROM employees e JOIN salesorders so ON e.EmployeeID = so.EmployeeID
JOIN (
    SELECT EmployeeID, COUNT(OrderID) AS TotalOrders
    FROM salesorders
    GROUP BY EmployeeID
) total_orders ON e.EmployeeID = total_orders.EmployeeID
WHERE so.Status = 'Cancelled'
GROUP BY e.EmployeeID
ORDER BY CancellationRate DESC
sql:
SELECT e.EmployeeID, COUNT(so.OrderID) AS Cancellations, (COUNT(so.OrderID) / total_orders.TotalOrders) AS CancellationRate
FROM employees e JOIN salesorders so ON e.EmployeeID = so.EmployeeID
JOIN (
    SELECT EmployeeID, COUNT(OrderID) AS TotalOrders
    FROM salesorders
    GROUP BY EmployeeID
) total_orders ON e.EmployeeID = total_orders.EmployeeID
WHERE so.Status = 'Cancelled'
GROUP BY e.EmployeeID
ORDER BY CancellationRate DESC
insights: The data shows the details of 13 employee records, each with an EmployeeID, Cancellations, and CancellationRate. The minimum CancellationRate is 0.3333, while the maximum and mean are both 1.0. There seems to be a mix of employees with CancellationRates of 1.0 (1081, 334, 1208, 1391, 430, 329, 428, 886, and 1004) and those with a lower rate of 0.5 (281).

sql:
SELECT c.CustomerName FROM customers c
JOIN (
    SELECT CustomerID, COUNT(OrderID) as PurchaseCount, MAX(OrderDate) as LastPurchase
    FROM salesorders so
    WHERE OrderDate >= DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), INTERVAL 3 YEAR)
    GROUP BY CustomerID
    HAVING PurchaseCount = 1
) cp ON c.CustomerID = cp.CustomerID
insights: The data shows a list of 192 unique customer names, each represented by a single entry in the provided dataset. No customer made more than one purchase as the CustomerName column only contains individual names without any repetition or additional information.

SELECT c.CustomerName, COUNT(DISTINCT p.ProductID) AS ProductVariety
FROM customers c JOIN salesorders so ON c.CustomerID = so.CustomerID
JOIN orderitems oi ON so.OrderID = oi.OrderID
JOIN products p ON oi.ProductID = p.ProductID
GROUP BY c.CustomerName
ORDER BY ProductVariety DESC LIMIT 5
sql:
SELECT c.CustomerName, COUNT(DISTINCT p.ProductID) AS ProductVariety
FROM customers c JOIN salesorders so ON c.CustomerID = so.CustomerID
JOIN orderitems oi ON so.OrderID = oi.OrderID
JOIN products p ON oi.ProductID = p.ProductID
GROUP BY c.CustomerName
ORDER BY ProductVariety DESC LIMIT 5

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
SELECT Industry, AVG(TotalSales) AS Average_Sales FROM (
  SELECT c.Industry, so.TotalAmount AS TotalSales FROM customers c
  JOIN salesorders so ON c.CustomerID = so.CustomerID
  GROUP BY c.Industry
) AS industry_sales ORDER BY Average_Sales DESC
sql:
SELECT Industry, AVG(TotalSales) AS Average_Sales FROM (
  SELECT c.Industry, so.TotalAmount AS TotalSales FROM customers c
  JOIN salesorders so ON c.CustomerID = so.CustomerID
  GROUP BY c.Industry
) AS industry_sales ORDER BY Average_Sales DESC
insights: The provided data shows that the average sales for the Agriculture industry is $29,644.93 per unit.
